reviewText: It's sad that such a excellent anime got butchered so badly by the American distributor Viz. On the advanced copy I was able to see thanks to Shonen Jump, I was instantly able to tell that this was definitely an inferior version of what Naruto the anime could have been. The voice acting stunk (it's great to here those neutral tones in moments of panic), the kid-friendly editing was unneeded (especially since most of the kids who are watching this on TV have already read the manga), and there wasn't a Japanese track. If this is true for the upcoming release of this anime, then it spells instant doom for Naruto the anime, because it just isn't worth watching in the English track.That being said, I will say that Naruto is possibly my favorite manga. It outranks even the mature manga I tend to read (Berserk, Hellsing, Death Note), which says something about the story of this manga. So all of you fan-boys and girls out there who are going to vote this review as unhelpful because I said something negative about you favorite, Naruto, think again. I'm fighting for Naruto, which was given an ill-luck chance on this side of the world with this anime release. I think Viz was more out to make money than anything, something an anime studio should not do because it alienates true fans of anime. By making it the way they did, they were able to sell it to Cartoon Network, and they could subsequently release the Uncut version after people have already bought the first couple volumes of the cut one.If I was you, a Naruto fan interested in the anime, I'd wait for the uncut version to be released. If luck is with us, the Japanese track will be on that version, the true version, and we won't have to listen to the terrible American voice acting, plus we'll get the full Naruto the way it was meant to be seen. Don't buy this; it just isn't worth the time and money.
summary: First Impressions: Wait for the Uncut Version

reviewText: Hey, guys!  Maybe different households want different things.  My family loves watching Naruto on Cartoon Network.  They love the storylines, the different characters, the unusualness of the world of Naruto.  But my husband and I don't WANT the kids to have the unedited version.  I have no problem with someone saying that this is not THEIR anime, but that doesn't mean that this isn't "real" anime.  Anime is growing up and out, like any entertainment or art form that's reaching a larger audience.  It is changing for different environments.  A purist won't like THIS verion of Naruto, but that's OK, this version isn't made for them, it's made for people like my family with younger kids.  I do wish that the CN version was available in a boxed set; buying individual episodes gets pricey.  When my kids are older, they may want the uncut version.  But the CN version is good for now!
summary: There's Nothing Wrong With the CN Verision
Title: N/A

reviewText: I watched the first Naruto episode almost to prove to myself that I wouldn't like it.  It looked like a silly kids anime that was way to popular to take seriously, but much to my surprise, I found the first episode somewhat touching.  Following episodes impressed me even more, and by the time my wife and I got through the first real mission (involving the bridge and Haku and what have you), we were both hooked.  From there the series gets only better, with an outstanding cast of characters and pretty strong animation.  Orochimaru is easily one of the five best villains I've ever seen in an anime.  It's a really long series (160+ episodes), but it is so fun and emotionally involving that you barely notice.  Over the course of a few months, I've seen about 140 episodes, and I would be perfectly happy seeing 140 more.  Highly recommended.Oh, and make sure you watch them in order or you're probably not going to like it.

reviewText: I watched some of the original version fan subbed and it was very good.  When I heard it got licensed, and was going to come out in the U.S. I was a bit worried.  Then I saw it on Toonami, and realized once again the americanization butchers got their cleavers in to another excellent series and turned something meant for 10+ to something for 5+.  The voice acting for the most part is very painful to listen to.  It reminds me of when Love Hina was released with american dubbing.  It's one of the few that when the original release of Naruto comes out (heard some time in July), I will get that, and just leave it on subbed.

reviewText: Naruto is one of the biggest anime in the world.  Since it's release in 2002, 171 episodes have aired each among the highest rated TV shows in Japan.  It's popularity in America began during late 2002.  The show was subbed and downloaded.  Then in 2003, Viz brought the manga to America in their Shonen Jump magazine.  The manga was, well it was plain bad.  The Jutsu were renamed and entire attitudes were changed.  However, its popularity kept going up and was eventually on the USA Today topselling books.  Then in spring 2005, Viz Media announced its dub of Naruto.  Now, we come to this actual product.One of the most dissapointing thing about this DVD is that Viz Media will not have the original Japanese audio track.  This seems to be a new trait of Viz Media all of a sudden, Konjiki no Gash Beru (Zatch Bell!) didn't have the original audio track on its first two volumes either.  Why is this dissapointing?  Well, many people were waiting for a bilingual DVD.  And also, no offense Viz Media, but the voice acting is terrible.  Naruto has this annoying habit of saying "Believe It!" which has no meaning what so ever, which means it is pretty close to "dattebayo!".  Naruto sounds a lot like the original voice actress, so I give them props there.  The script is really close to the original.  A lot of the yelling and threat lines seem half hearted.  As of now, it is unknown if they are going to make this DVD uncut.  The show has been changed very little.  The background music is the same, however, blood that flows has been removed and the scene when Naruto and Sasuke are kissing on accident.  I have to give props to Viz Media for not saying Ninja Centerfold or Art of the Doppleganger in their dub.  The opening and ending them of the show has been changed DRASTICALLY!  Originally the theme songs were ROCK! and Wind for these episodes, these songs were more country/acoustic rock type and well rock.  Viz Media put this guitar, sound effect, drums song that is very common in many Shonen anime dubs.Pros-BGM hasn't been changed-Voices are authentic (sound like that character)-The script is pretty close to the original.Cons-Theme song has been changed and terrible.-Some things have been edited-The disc doesn't have Japanese audio track/subtitles (this is a real con for serious anime/Naruto fans but not so much for just a child of whatever)-Some voice actors are terrible at making emotionsSo who are you?  One who is a really big anime fan who enjoys listening to the original audio track?  One who enjoys J-Pop?  Purist fan?If you are these, skip this DVD.If you are the exact opposite, then go ahead, by all means buy this disc.
summary: Really, based on your point of view.

reviewText: That is what you'll get on this, the first (of many) DVD volumes to the mega-hit that has been sweeping the world's population of anime fans.In these 4 episodes, you are introduced to the 3 'major' characters (Naruto Uzumaki, Sasuke Uchida, and Sakura Haruno), and the story gets off the ground.  As previous reviewers have stated, the fights sort of take a 'DBZ" approach, spreading them out over multiple episodes to allow for more drama.  However, also as stated previous, these are not your 'lightning fast paced, beat-em-up-until-they-bleed' fights that DBZ is famous for.  NO, these are the kinds of battles the three 'main' characters, along with their instructor, Kakashi, have to strategize with...to think through all of their options,  their consequences and outcomes.  Those tense moments seem to be what keep the fans coming for more each week in Japan.  It's already been done 170-some weeks, and for the past 20-some here in the U.S.  The manga is quite popular as well.The English dub, it's not all that bad.  I've been an anime fan for almost 10 years, and 99% of what I've seen has been with the familiar (to me) language of English selected.  As usual with English recordings, these first 4 episodes see the cast 'warming up' to their roles, so there are bound to be some mistakes and instances of the voice actors 'finding their voice' that suits their character best.  Do not listen to the die-hard fanatics when deciding on purchasing this DVD.  If you are into English-dubbed anime because you like them, or just want it in a familiar language so you can enjoy the visuals on screen, or (in my case, due to poor vision) have a hard time with headache-inducing subtitles, this dub works, and it works well enough here in its edited form.So why am I giving this, the much loathed (by die-hard fans) release 5 stars?  Simple.  It's because no matter what format you take this show in, be it the truncated CN airing, or the forthcoming Un-edited box set (the first of many I'm sure), Naruto is just a fun series to watch..a good time-killer anime.-Now this part of the review is for the parents shopping here @ Amazon-:  As stated, this release will be the edit seen on Toonami, that Saturday prime-time block on Cartoon Network.  This is, in other words, "Naruto Lite", and I recommend this for the younger fans who aren't allowed to watch the more violent scenes and blood (toned down here, but there still may be instances of blood in only the most importaint scenes).  There's also some humor in here that 'may' not be sutable, but what is and is not sutable for kids is not for me to judge.  Even in this edited form, I would still not let anyone too young (say, 6-7-8'ish) to see this series.  It's still quite violent, and has some humor that may not be sutable for them.  Finally, this 'edit' release is only going to be in English, so there's no needing to fiddle around with the 'Audio selection' on your player.
summary: For What It Is, The CN Version Isn't THAT bad!

reviewText: When I first saw Naruto, my impressions from then and now have not differed. I think is a passable anime, but it definitely did not blow me away. To me, it is more plot-detailed version of Pokemon. I stopped watching Naruto when I realised that there where more than a hundred episodes. I'm the kind of person who likes 26 episode series. Not only that, Naruto is so long becuase each episode contains like a 15 minute recap of what happened previous episode. In the end, it is a spiralling vortex of flashbacks, and my head hurts thinking about it. This is one of those shows you watch on TV, not dish out tons of dollars for. The animation is average, and the characters are a cliched sort of fleshed-out. That is, Naruto is an alienated orphan with a terrible childhood. Okay, that's a good character development start. Reminding me EVERY EPISODE that he is an alienated orphan with a terrible childhood is NOT GOOD. That's all.

reviewText: I started watching Naruto when the fansubbers first started doing it, and ever since I've been anticipating its American release.  Naruto is one of my favorite series.  But I will not be buying these DVDs until Viz does it properly.I, for one, did not like the English dub.  Some of the voices just grate on my ears, and others have no emotion whatsoever.  The Japanese voice actors are in a whole other league than those featured on this dub, and Viz would likely sell more DVDs if they offered a bilingual track.Worse than that, they are only offering an edited copy.  If any of you folks at Viz happen upon this page, here's a news flash: children are not the only ones who watch anime!  If you want to market an anime for children, fine.  But pick one that was orignally aimed at children.  Don't pick a violent, bloody series with mildly-sexual scenes and water it down.  Even if you feel the need to do that, at least offer a copy that isn't edited so you don't exclude half of your audience.I love Naruto, but Viz has really ruined it.  Konjiki no Gash Bell, another show I enjoy, has been treated the same.  Its simply a shame that Viz got a hold of them instead of another company.
summary: Viz used to be near the top of the game, now it's sinking straight to the bottom...
Title: N/A

reviewText: I would suggest you watch at least one episode on Toonami before purchasing this. That way you get an estimate of how many times an episode Naruto say's "Believe it!"For the american version of this you come to realize that they make Naruto out to be overly obnoxious and annoying. While in the Japanese version he doesn't act near this annoying. Sure he's annoying at the begining, but he hasn't matured yet. In later episodes it shows that he's matured a lot (still makes his random mistakes, and is a bit proud... ot proud to admit he's wrong, or inferrior in some ways.)I'm not sure how this edited version turned out, maybe they take out specific words and replace them with "dang" and remove the blood. which is ok if your below the age of 14... But if you think about it, it removes the overall feeling of the struggles of a ninja.Overall Viz did a horrible job casting voice actors (with the exception of, Shikimaru, and one or two others.) Shino sounds like a bloated retard, when he's supposed to give you the feeling of a mysterious, calm, and goth personality..I dread to see what they do to Bleach, since Viz picked that up too. (Bleach, Naruto, and Full Metal Alchemist are my top three anime, and so far Full Metal Alchemist was the only on to get royal treatment... we'll see how Bleach Fairs, once voicing actors are casted.)Sound: 2 out of 5Voice acting is annoying, some lines are over used.Musical score, is the same as in Japanese version which is perfect for the theme of this show. If it has the option to watch it in Japanese with subtitles, do yourself a favor and do that... Your ears will thank you.Animation: 4 out of 5Animation flows smoothly and fits the story well.Story: 4 out of 5The story is deep and takes a lot of twists. The downfall here is that it progresses a bit slowly, but that in turn makes the show last longer.

reviewText: Okay this is one of my favorite animes. But if i were you i would wait for the uncut version or better yet buy the japanese version w/english subs. Its not that the show is actually horrible on the CW but the CW's version is watered down...if your like me then you hate it when things get cut out, thats what they do.Its been turned into a kids anime which really isn't what it is if you watch the origional version. The voice acting is good i will have to say that but the japanese voices are great to and the soundtrack in the japanese version is amazing...although some of the music is the same in the english version some of my favorite songs are the ones at the begining and end of the episodes and those are not in the english version.Like I said before wait for the uncut version (I hope they put it out in a box set when the whole series is done) or get the origional Japanese version if you don't mind reading subtitles it really is worth it.
